title: Week 2: January 5–11 - Moses 1; Abraham 3
content:
# Week 2: I Am a Child of God (Moses 1; Abraham 3)

## Lesson Overview
Children will discover they are children of God with divine worth and purpose, as revealed to Moses and Abraham. This truth helps 8-10-year-olds feel valued, resist Satan's lies, and choose eternal perspectives in daily decisions (Moses 1:4, 12; Abraham 3:22–28). Knowing their premortal spirit identity builds confidence to follow God's plan.

## Opening Activity (5 minutes): Mirror Messages (Object Lesson)
Hold up a hand mirror and invite each child to look into it while you read Moses 1:4. Say together: "You are a child of God!" Have them repeat it to a partner.  
*Materials*: Small hand mirror (or phone reflection).  
This grabs attention by making the principle personal, echoing God's words to Moses (Moses 1:4).

## Scripture Focus
**Moses 1:4**: "And thou art my son; wherefore look and I will show thee the workmanship of mine hands; but not all, for my works are without end, and also my words, for they never cease."  
*Child-friendly*: God told Moses, "You are my son!" just like He says to each of us—we are His precious children with endless worth.  

**Abraham 3:22–23** (excerpt): "Now the Lord had shown unto me, Abraham, the intelligences that were organized before the world was; and among all these there were many of the noble and great ones; And God saw these souls that they were good, and he stood in the midst of them, and he said: These I will make my rulers..."  
*Child-friendly*: Before earth, we lived as spirits with Heavenly Father—many were noble and good, chosen for important work here.

## Main Activities (15-20 minutes total)

### 1. God's Truth Toss (Game, 5 minutes)
**Activity Type**: Games  
**Steps**: Write 6 phrases on cards (3 true from God like "You are my child" [Moses 1:4]; 3 false from Satan like "You are nothing" [Moses 1:12]). Toss a beanbag; child reads card aloud, says "God" or "Satan," and tosses to next. Switch teams for speed.  
**Materials**: Beanbag (or balled sock), 6 index cards, marker.  
**Connection**: Helps spot God's affirming messages vs. Satan's counterfeits, like Moses did (Moses 1:12–26).  
**Questions**: "How did Moses reply to Satan? (Moses 1:13, 15, 18). What truths make you feel strong?"

### 2. Premortal Spirit Parade (Music & Movement, 5 minutes)
**Activity Type**: Music & Movement  
**Steps**: Teach "I Will Follow God’s Plan" (Children’s Songbook, 164–65). March in a circle singing; add actions—point up for "before I came to earth," flex muscles for "prove," hug self for "child of God." Pause to draw quick stick-figure spirits in notebooks.  
**Materials**: Printed lyrics (optional), notebooks/pencils.  
**Connection**: Reinforces premortal life truths—we chose to come prove ourselves (Abraham 3:22–28).  
**Questions**: "What words like 'before the world was' or 'spirits' did you find? (Abraham 3:22–28). How does this change your choices?"

### 3. Resist Like Moses Skit (Role-Play & Acting, 5-7 minutes)
**Activity Type**: Role-Play & Acting  
**Steps**: Divide into 3 groups. Assign scenes from Moses 1:12–26: Group 1—Moses sees God’s glory (v. 13–15); Group 2—Satan tempts, Moses commands "Get thee hence" (v. 20–22); Group 3—God sends angel (v. 26). Use scarves as robes; act with big voices, then perform for class.  
**Materials**: Scarves or paper towels as props.  
**Connection**: Shows how Moses resisted Satan by remembering his divine identity and calling for help (Moses 1:12–26).  
**Questions**: "What helped Moses win? (Pray, remember God’s power [v. 24–26]). How can Jesus help us?"

## Testimony Time (3 minutes)
Sit in a circle. Pass a soft ball; child holding it shares one feeling, like "I feel happy knowing I'm God's child" (prompt: "What do you feel when you remember you are a child of God?"). Listen warmly—Heavenly Father loves their simple words.

## Take-Home Challenge
Each night, look in a mirror and say, "I am a child of God" (Moses 1:4). Draw one way you'll follow His plan that day.

## Teacher Tips
Use a timer for smooth transitions; pair shy children with buddies. For wiggly groups, add jumping jacks between activities. (Total: 612 words)
